Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: many features, auto exposure, presets, battery life (Li-ion), easy to use on "auto"
Cons: A little difficult to find certain settings when you want to change them manually, and video not the best
While it's no SLR -- it's packs quite a punch regardless.
I bought this to replace my Canon PowerShot A590IS because I was going through AA batteries like crazy. I decided to stay with Canon because of all the features that they include in these little guys -- you have almost complete control over your shoot. From exposure settings to white balance settings (tungsten, cloudy, fluorescent, et...), even custom lighting/white-balancing that you can set to whatever you like. There are also preset settings like "portrait" which will blur the background so the subject is the m ... ain focus, "night", "indoor", "kids/pets", And THEN there's "low-lighting" "snow", "beach" "foilage" etc... they're all included on this camera too.
The "auto" setting is amazing by itself, but if you want more control there is a "manual" setting. However, you do have to do a little exploring to find certain features (hence the 4 instead of 5 for "ease of use"). The book that comes with it is extremely lacking. No manual, just a "getting started" guide. Should be included, but they at least offer a PDF (full-manual guide) that you can view and/or download from Canon's website.
Picture quality....amazing! Auto Exposure does an amazing job of compensating for those bad lighting situations.
Battery life -- AWESOME! I used to have to bring two or three diff. sets of batteries for only a couple of hours of shooting (photos alone) with my older PowerShot. With the rechargeable battery Li-ion, I can go on several shootings (different days) without ever getting "low" warning-- and that's mixing it up using both photos and video.
Video -- not so hot (not terrible either), but this is a digital camera, not a digital movie camera. The largest size is only 640 x 480 px and you need really good lighting. But with video editing software it's really easy to fix the lighting. Zoom quality is horrendous, but if you're looking to take great quality home videos then you should buy a video camera. lol
Completely a ... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: 4X optical zoom in a small size. Great pictures. Good shot-to-shot recycle times.
Cons: No optical view finder. Care needed in focusing under low light conditions. Battery life?
I bought the SD1300IS the day after it was put on display at my local Best Buy store. My aim was to replace an older but still faithful Canon A-540 (10,000+ shots) with something smaller and with Canon's updated lighting, program and sensor features. So far, after over 200 pictures and video clips, I have not been disappointed.
I spent time up-front going through the operator's manual page by page (camera in hand) learning how to utilize the SD1300's features and controls. It has paid off due to the differences between the my old A and the SD ELPH series cameras.
I have noticed the ... SD1300 recycles faster between shots, especially with the flash on. I do miss the mode dial on top of the A-540.
The SD1300 seems to not focus well in some lower light conditions unless you "prefocus" first by depressing the shutter button half way.
Battery life seems shorter than the A540 (had rechargeable AA's) but not all bad with a "useful" battery monitor display. A spare Canon battery is much more expensive than rechargeable AA's.
The Low Light setting appears to have promising capabilities during poor lighting conditions but I am still experimenting with the results under varying situations.
I have owned several Canon "point and shoot" cameras over the years and this one promises to be a good one also. I can only hope it is as reliable and rugged as my A-540 has been. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I started out shooting 35mm film 10 years ago. About 5 years ago I switched to 1.6 crop digital. Very recently I bought a SD1300. My wife calls it my toy camera., I wanted a more convenient camera. The day after I received the SD1300 I put it through it's paces. I took back lit, wife in front of window night snapshot, ie fill flash worked fine. We went to the park I took a shot with the setting sun behind her using ???2 exposure compensation brought out the shadow details in PS using curves. Would have preferred fill light with RAW editor but curves was almost as good. Took a macro shot of a flower in the park. Took landscapes with tree line in middle ground and building in background, worked fine. Shut-off flash, set ISO to 400 and took low light shots. I was able to take fairly sharp sh ... ots at 1/8 sec. With the exception of bracketing, saving RAW and a meaningful DOF pretty much came close to my other cameras. After all it's about the size a pack of cigarettes and weighs less than 5 ozs. The major paradigm shift is the DOF. Pretty much everything is in focus. Background blur is not possible. After I did some quick calculations I figured out why. Large format uses f64 for a lot of DOF, medium format 32, 35mm 16, 1.6 crop 11. Since, the size of this camera is so small 5-20mm equals 28-112 35mm. Holy cow batman, that's a a multiplier of 5.6.. So on this camera f2.8 is roughly the same as f16 on 35mm and f5.9 is f32. So, the camera always shoots wide open, as it should. I spent my life in aperture priority on my other cameras. But here it's always wide open. So, that's not part of the equation anymore. My one complaint is the algorithm that it uses to set exposure. It changes ISO as much or more than shutter speed. I find that annoying. So, I suggest that you set the thing in the middle setting, P or camera mode as it's called. Pick you're ISO and White Balance and let the camera decide the shutter speed. I'd also suggest that you turn on iConstrast and set folder names to daily. Start with ISO at 80 for bright lights and work you way up as the light diminishes and shutter speeds get down to around 1/8. I also set focus on the middle with small rectangle. As I've said with the widest aperture at f16 pretty much everything is going to focus, so don't get to carried away with focus. With the AIAF one of the main, if not the primary purpose, of this camera is party snaps (birthdays, anniversaries, graduations, holidays, dates, special events etc..) and vacation snaps. For these it works perfectly. Would you get better images with a DSLR with several lens? Of course you would. How much better? In most cases not a whole lot. Is it worth one the cost and the effort lugging all that equipment around? Only you can decide that. For me when I'm spending several grand to go on vacation, let's say in Europe, I'm taking my full DSLR kit. When I'm going to my niece's birthday or to a New Years Eve party or a walk around town the DSLR stay's home and I'm taking the SD1300. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: IT IS CLASSY AND IT TAKES GREAT PICTURES
Item.Review: I am going to try to share what I have discovered about this camera. These are just my thoughts. Some things I am compairing to a canon SD1200 and the SD940. The flat button arangement is the same as the SD1200 all but the power button on top is larger and easier to turn off and on,I like that but be carefull it does not come on in your pocket. I have not had any trouble using any of the buttons even with my big old hands. I like that the mic for the video is in the frount of the camera instead of being on the top like the canon SD940,it picks up less noise being in the frount. I like the func menu(where you set iso, white ballance, my colors) better than the SD940 because it lets you set things with one less step like the SD1200 and it has a better color skeem(the color of the menus) than ... the canon 1200, that just me though. I can not tell any differnce in shot to shot or flash shot to shot times between the SD1300 and the SD1200 which is 1 and 1/2secs to 2secs with out flash and 3 to 4secs with flash on(up to 6secs for full flash recharge). Shutter lag is good for a canon point and shoot but if you prefocas that will help even more. I never tested the continuous shooting( but see my battery test) but canon says it is 0.9 per sec where the sd 1200 is 1.4 shots per sec, if that is important to you. I did test the battery by using continuous shooting with the flash on and got well over 400 pictures and still had 3 bars left on the battery icon and it was taking 1 picture every 2 seconds or less if that helps you out on the continuous shooting part and when I turned the flash off it seemed to be very fast. I am getting about the same image quality as the SD 1200 which is very good for this size point and shoot camera and getting a 2.7inch very clear LCD screen and a 28mm x 112mm lens a little better (than the 35 x 105 on the SD1200). This is just me but I would stay away from the auto mode indoors(it works good outdoors in bright light though), it seems to want to use a very high iso which makes your picture look grainy or snowing looking, it would be ok for 4x6x prints?. I use program mode and set the iso to 100 or 200 iso (if possable).For some reason canon has done this wih all thier newer point and shoot cameras the last year or two, I know (it is a bummer)... With the SD1200 and SD940 I would use program mode and auto iso but when trying to do that with the SD1300 it wants to go to 500iso some times where the 1200 and 940 would go to 250iso ,go figure? A lot of the review sites blow thier pictures way up and look for defects,your likely to only make 5x7 or 8x10s and not see (what they see). If you are going to make larger prints you could go to a canon S90 or the bigger G11, but much more money I know!>Just keep the iso down and you will do good...) Just a thought I wish they would of stayed at 10 megapixles because of the small sensor... The SD1300 has a touch more style, larger LCD and a little more virsatle lens, but the 1200 is also a very good camera. Try (neutral) in (my colors menu) and see what you think with your indoor shots of the kids if your not happy with the default color? I posted some pictures on this site for the SD1300, theirs just not much color her yet but they will give you some idea untill some one can post some good pictures. I mostly take pictures of bear in the smokey mountians (CADES COVE) and love chaseing the grand kids around taking their pictures expand » « collapse

I have a full-featured DSLR camera, but for small parties or get-togethers with friends it's too cumbersome. This camera is a great alternative and offers excellent features in a small package and for a decent price. For casual photography I have enjoyed this camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small / Compact; Large Clear LCD; Nice Body Color; Easy To Use; Good Image Quality
Cons: Slippery in the hand
Love this little camera. Great looks, great performance, cheap price. Plenty of megapixels and a great LCD for so little money. Takes great pics, especially with the flash--doesn't blow out your subjects. I'm using primarily as a point-and-shoot party camera and it's perfect for that. Only con is the ergonomics in your hand. Nothing to really grip it with and so it's a little slippery. I'd recommend getting one of those straps where you can pull the bead down to make it tight around your wrist. My last little Canon came with that kind of strap, but sadly, this one doesn't, and needs it. Otherwise, bravo Canon!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I have to say the feature performs as expected. Obviously it's not going to do much if there is a lot of camera shake, but it does the job for what it's intended to do. Picture quality is excellent. It does well in Low light as well. Manual settings do just as well as auto settings. I like the playback button that lets you review pics rather than having to switch the camera into another mode. When taking multiple shots the lag time between pics is minimal. Videos work well with it but there is that pesky no in and out zoom during a video. Sound quality was surprisingly good with video mode as well. It takes outdoor video well with little wind noise. I was a bit cautious about buying a camera with no viewfinder as my last camera had one, but let's face it, I hardly used it when I had it. In ... sisting on a camera with a viewfinder also significantly limited my choices for point and shoots. I'm satisfied with no viewfinder and this camera is exactly what I expect in a good point and shoot. Battery life is great! Even under moderate to heavy use it lasted all night and part of the next day. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: can't beat this compact for price
Item.Review:
Pros: Fast/accurate auto-focus; Good Image Quality; Small / Compact; Easy To Use
Cons: Some yellow indoors; Colors may wash out
This camera is incredibly light and stylish. It is one of the few left with wide angle in this price range. It can take incredible pictures and is great for travel, especially outdoor shots. Downside: you really need to frame your shots and play with the settings in order to get truly great pics, but that is true with any camera. It is easy to use for beginners who just want to point and shoot, but watch indoor and low light shots. Bad shots will show on the lcd and the camera won't settle when you half press the shutter if it can't reach a good speed in that light. Overall and amazing camera for the price.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: It is classy and it takes great pictures
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good image quality; Good Image Stabilization
Cons: NO CAMERA IS PERFECT
These are just (my thoughts) I hope they might help a little. (Some things) I am compairing to a canon SD1200 and the SD940. The flat button arangement is the same as the SD1200 all but the power button on top is larger and easier to turn off and on, I like that but be carefull it does not come on in your pocket. I have not had any trouble using any of the buttons even with my big old hands. The SD1300 is very easy to use. Some will miss the viewfinder that the SD1200 had and some will miss the HD 720p in the movie mode that the SD940 has, The SD1300 has 640x480 at 30fps like the canon SD1200 G11 and S90. I like that the mic for the video is in the frount of the camera instead of being on the t ... op (where I put my finger) like the canon SD940 SD970 and others, it picks up less finger movement noise being in the frount. I can not tell any difference in shot to shot or flash shot to shot times between the SD1300 and the SD1200 which is 2secs with out the flash, and 3 to 4secs with the flash on, (( up to 6secs for full flash recharge )). Shutter lag is good for a canon point and shoot but if you prefocas that will help even more. I never tested the continuous shooting( but see my battery test) but canon says it is 0.9 per sec where the sd 1200 is 1.4 shots per sec, if that is important to you. I did test the battery (NB-6L same battery as SD1200) by using continuous shooting with the flash on and got well over 400 pictures and it was taking ( 1 picture every 2 seconds or less in the continuous mode if that helps you out on the continuous shooting part) and when I turned the flash off it seemed to be very fast. In real life your get around 300 to 350 pictures with some of them using the flash, your still need a second battery for a backup. I am getting about the same image quality as the SD 1200 which is very good for this size point and shoot camera and getting a 2.7inch very clear LCD screen and a 28mm x 112mm lens a little better (than the 35 x 105 on the SD1200). This is just me, I am no expert but I like using the program mode best and try not to use the auto mode indoors ((auto works good outdoors in good light tho) auto seems to want to use a very high iso indoors which makes your pictures look grainy or snowy looking on larger prints, it would be ok for a 4x6 or 5x7 print?. I use program mode and set the iso to 100 or 200 iso (if possable indoors), (I like 80 or 100iso for the best image quality if you have anough good light indoors or outdoors ). For some reason canon has done this with all there newer point and shoot cameras the last year or two, (I know it is a bummer) and again this is just me), You might be happy with the pictures you take in auto mode... With the SD1200 and SD940 I would use program mode and auto iso but when trying to do that with the SD1300 it wants to go to 500iso some times where the 1200 and 940 would go to 250iso ,go figure? A lot of the review sites blow there pictures way up and look for defects, your likely to only make 5x7 or 8x10s and not see (what they see). If you are going to make larger prints or need a better low light camera and still stay in a point and shoot you could go with a canon S90 or the bigger G11,but (much more money I know)! Just keep the iso down and you will do good...) Just a thought I wish they would of stayed at 10 megapixles because of the small sensor. The SD1300 seems to have a nice sharp lens but highlights sometimes tend to blow out in very bright sun as with all small cameras this size, you can see this in some of the pictures I posted on this sight for the 1300. But to be fair my G11 does this also. No problem with red eye in pictures useing the SD1300. The menu screens are easy to read... The SD1300 has a touch more style, larger LCD and a little more virsatle lens than the SD1200, but the 1200 is also a very good camera. The SD1300 does have a weak battery door cover like the SD1200. Small enough to carry every place you go for those spontaneous grandkid pictures... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I am an advanced amateur who also just bought a Canon EOS T3i SLR. I bought one of these (silver) for myself as pocket camera to use when I didn't want to schlep my SLR..like to dinners or other events where the SLR would be too bulky. I also steered my girlfriend to get one to replace her old broken camera and, so far, she is happy with it. The reviews were very good on [@] and I am generally happy with the camera and the pics. It is small, light and the screen is big. I wish it had a viewfinder for sunny days when it is hard to see the screen. The 28mm equivalent wide angle is good for squeezing people into those inevitable group shots. Like in all point and shoot cameras, I don't like the lag between pictures or the shutter lag. (That's one reason I have an SLR too). My only complaint i ... s that it may not focus on the subject you want and there is no manual focus. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality and image stabilization.
Cons: Not as many features as you would like.
This thing is the most powerful little sucker I've ever owned. Picture quality is the best I've ever used out of a point and shoot (I've used about 15 other cameras). I'm on a yearbook staff so I have had the oppertunity to use many cameras. Granted this camera doesn't take slr quality pictures, but it's the best you will get from a point and shoot.
There aren't as many features on this camera as i would have liked. There is no HD video which almost made me chose another camera. There arent that many scene modes either, I think there are 5. Also there is no charging the battery in the camera, but the picture quality make up for all of that.
Side note: there is a cable th ... at allows you to see your pictures on the t.v. it is a nice addition to this amazing camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small size, great photo quality, long battery life, great price and value, easy to use!
Cons: Not much zoom.
I absolutely adore this camera. I'm a student with very limited funds, so I can't afford a really fancy expensive camera. And you know what? I don't even need one, this camera does the trick. It is compact, fast to use, simple to figure out, and takes great quality photos. When someone stole this camera from my coat one night, I cried--then went and bought the exact same one from Best Buy. I didn't even look at the other options. This camera is everything I need. Someday, I would like to buy a higher-zoom camera for taking nature photos, but for now, this one does the trick. Good work Canon--you made a great camera for a low price.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: This is a solid point & shoot. Great for the pocket, although I have an older one (400 series) which is heavier but has a solid metal body which I prefer. The 1300 is slimmer, much lighter, but I haven't dropped it yet so I can't comment on its durability in that regard yet (my 400 survived numerous drops and still works well). Traded up because this was reasonably priced for double the image resolution. Still won't replace my DSLR, but for casual parties, discrete tourist photos, or just keeping in a backpack it takes great pictures. I do wish there was less lag, but you can't have everything. For the size and the price it was a great purchase.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)

I was very surprised at the good quality of the images and how great it shot in low light without the use of a flash. Very responsive and very good battery life. Extremely pleased with the quality for the price.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: It's a great camera. We've had Sonys before, but have had problems in the family with 3 different aging Sonys getting finicky. My MIL has had her Canon for 4 + yrs and no problems so we made the switch (along with other recommendations). I wanted a view finder, but this camera does not have one. It'll be fine as long as Canon is the reliable camera it's supposed to be. The LARGE LCD screen is great and can really be a good way to show off pictures too! What's also neat is that if you rotate the camera when reviewing the pictures it'll rotate the picture too... it knows it's down from up. The pictures are good quality and the video is also dramatically better than our previous camera. Be sure to get a BIG memory card though! 8GB is what we got, and I'm glad we didn't get anythin ... g smaller because we're using this as a video camera too. Why carry around 2 pieces of equipment? For us Overstock was truly the best deal price wise and they had it in stock! We love our PowerShot! ... expand » « collapse

Captures crisp images, but I am still learning how to reset it for lower lighting situations. Great value for the price. I purchased the Overstock.com extended warranty that I thought was reasonably priced. When the extended warranty runs and the camera runs its course I know I can trade it in at Canon with their loyalty program. Canon cameras rock!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small, stylish, fast start-up.
Cons: Lack of scenes, can't control focus point easily, no manual control.
I've owned this camera for a month and have taken just over 500 pics, mostly outdoor scenes, some macro indoor and out, kids indoors. So far I'm disappointed with this camera.
I like: it's size and feel, quick start-up, plus 1 face timer is pretty cool, custom timer, internal battery for keeping settings when removing the battery,
I don't like: Canon's function menu structure (I guess I'm getting used to it), no key customization, that it doesn't remember focus settings when powered off, it's difficult to focus where you want, aperture seems too narrow, even on infinity focus it has to find something to focus on causing a lag, has very few scenes ... (no sunset filter, no flowing water shot), can't force where you'd like it to focus.
I guess Canon doesn't want to put these features in a sub-compact camera, they probably want you to buy an SLR for $500. Or maybe I got spoiled with these features on the two previous sub-compacts I owned (Casio Exilm's believe it or not. Loved them.) expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice Body Color; Good Image Stabilization
Cons: Limited Zoom
It was a nice photograph. You will get the value for the money you spent. I wants to go for small and handy camera and this fits perfectly.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: Photography is my hobby. I take this camera when I travel due to it's size and weight. The photos and videos I've taken to date have produced good to very good results. It thin, light with a large screen and is a good value for the price.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: easy to use, best deal, sturdy, takes great pictures, loads quickly
Cons: doesnt stand up well, falls over, no panoramic setting, deleting unwanted pictures takes awhile
I bought this camera after seeing how nice my neighbor's was. Their camera had only 10 megapixels, so It was nice to see that I could get the 12 megapixel camera for even a cheaper price than they got theirs. (Their camera was an older version) I took this camera on vacation and it took abcolutely stunning pictures of all the scenery. It had a really nice feature that let you change the color to sepia or black and white before you took the picture, which I liked. It was also very easy to figure out how to use, I didn't read the manual at all and I already feel like a pro. However, I was disappointed tha ... t you only have two choices when it comes to deleting photos: delete them one at a time, or delete ALL of them all at once. my old camera (which was a sony cybershot W150) let you select only the images you wanted to delete, and the deleting process wasnt so time-consuming. I liked how the Sony cameras now have the Panorama setting to take panoramic pictures; sadly, this camera does not have that feature. Overall, very good, very durable piece of equipment which I hope will last a couple years. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice Body Color; Good Image Stabilization; Short Lag Time; Very happy so far
I love that it is small enough and had the belt carrying case. Can take it anywhere and it is so compact. It is so light you can have it with you where ever you go so you do not have to miss a shot

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Size, Ease to use, Price
Cons: short bettery life
I purchased this camera for family photo. It was great Price and features. This will be best choice if you have to choose camera. only one bad thing is short bettery life, but it is enough for a day.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I bought this as a mother's day present for my mom, and after a short tutorial she was taking decent pictures. The shutter release delay is small compared to some other cameras in the same price range, which is very important to me. You can also shoot short video clips.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: Good camera with useful functions and easy interface - battery has good life. Takes a moment to focus, lighting difficult to gauge and is sometimes inconsistent. Overall quality is good, size is convenient, and interface is very workable.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Sharp images and color quality. Does particularly well taking pictures in the dark! Long battery life, too!
Cons: It's starting to malfunction already
I never had a camera before. All I knew is I didn't want one that would distort colors or give me something grainy. I shopped long and hard starting off with SLR cameras knowing they had the best quality... I bought one and felt it was too pricey. I didn't get my money's worth- so I sent it back right away. I bought another- a hot pink point-and-shoot from Samsung. It was fine until one of its reviewers brought to my attention its off-colored photos. I thought I could bare it because the camera itself was such a pretty color, but after taking a few pictures, I couldn't stand it. I'd bought a new shirt and put on some othe ... r whatnot for a great photo (loving the color of everything) and all of the colors came out darkened- almost sad-looking. The pictures looked cold and lifeless. I took that in a very well lit area, too. Pictures in the dark were out of the question. I sent that one back. FINALLY I came across this beauty! It was much smaller than the others. I worried about trading out my old camera for one that had .3 less pixles, but I thought to give it a try for its high satisfaction rates. It turned out to be my best first camera ever! The colors are warmer, I can take pictures in the dark (without always having to use a flash or special setting). Pictures come out a little grainy sometimes- but only sometimes! Most of the pictures I've taken with this have come out fantastic!! I love it when my targets move, because sometimes even that'll turn out pretty cool! After all of my shopping, I learned to trust what the people say and that Canon truly is a great camera company. Keep in mind that I bought this before Canon produced it's 14 pixel series. If you can, I suggest you tried one of those, but if not, you wouldn't be sorry with this one. I'm very happy with it and definately got my money's worth! :D expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: It is classy and it takes great pictures
Item.Review:
Pros: Takes great pictures; Good Image Stabilization; It is easy to use; Good battery life; Has good zoom range
Cons: NO CAMERA IS PERFECT
These are just my thoughts. Some things I am compairing to a canon SD1200 and the SD940. The flat button arangement is the same as the SD1200 all but the power button on top is larger and easier to turn off and on,I like that but be carefull it does not come on in your pocket. I have not had any trouble using any of the buttons even with my big old hands. ((Some will miss the viewfinder that the SD1200 had)). I like that the mic for the video is in the frount of the camera instead of being on the top (where I put my finger) like the canon SD940,it picks up less noise being in the frount. I like the func menu(where you set iso, white ballan ... ce, my colors) better than the SD940 because it lets you set things with one less step like the SD1200 and it has a better menu color skeem (the print color of the menus) than the canon 1200, thats just me tho.. I can not tell any differnce in shot to shot or flash shot to shot times between the SD1300 and the SD1200 which is (1 and 1/2secs) to (2secs) with out flash and 3 to 4secs with flash on(up to 6secs for full flash recharge). Shutter lag is good for a canon point and shoot but if you prefocas that will help even more. I never tested the continuous shooting( but see my battery test) but canon says it is 0.9 per sec where the sd 1200 is 1.4 shots per sec, if that is important to you. I did test the battery (NB-6L same as SD1200) by using continuous shooting with the flash on and got well over 400 pictures and still had 3 bars left on the battery icon and it was taking 1 picture every 2 seconds or less if that helps you out on the continuous shooting part and when I turned the flash off it seemed to be very fast. I am getting about the same image quality as the SD 1200 which is very good for this size point and shoot camera and getting a 2.7inch very clear LCD screen and a 28mm x 112mm lens a little better (than the 35 x 105 on the SD1200). This is just me but I would stay away from the auto mode indoors(it works good outdoors in good light tho), it seems to want to use a very high iso indoors in auto which makes your picture look grainy or snowy looking, it would be ok for 4x6x prints?. I use program mode and set the iso to 100 or 200 iso (if possable).For some reason canon has done this with all thier newer point and shoot cameras the last year or two, I know (((it is a bummer)))... With the SD1200 and SD940 I would use program mode and auto iso but when trying to do that with the SD1300 it wants to go to 500iso some times where the 1200 and 940 would go to 250iso ,go figure? >>> A lot of the review sites blow thier pictures way up and look for defects, your likely to only make 5x7 or 8x10s and not see (what they see). If you are going to make larger prints or need a low light camera you could go to a canon (S90) or the bigger (G11), but much more money I know!>Just keep the iso down and you will do good...) Just a thought I wish they would of stayed at 10 megapixles because of the small sensor... The SD1300 has a touch more style, larger LCD and a little more virsatle lens, but the 1200 is also a very good camera. You do not get a SD card with the camera and if your new to this digital camera stuff remember to low level format the SD card. >((I carry my camera in a little phone case that has a belt clip not a loop for fast & easy on and off the belt)) I definitely recommend picking up a small camera case for protection. I mostly take pictures of bear in the Smokey Mountians (CADES COVE) and love chaseing the grand kids around taking their pictures. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I bought this camera in March 2011 and I get a lot of compliments on the quality of my pictures, the ease of use, and the features for this camera. I also love the fact that is has a rechargeable battery. I use it for both business and pleasure. I would definitely buy this camera again. It s cute and light weight and just perfect for me!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: Very easy to use, and produces great, clear shots. Auto-focus takes the 'thinking' out of shooting. The image quality, even in shooting concerts + video was incredibly sharp.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
After struggling to find an easy to use digital camera I went with the Powershot. I was very happy with the photos it took. They seemed to snap quickly (not quite quick enough sometimes for my kids, but better than most). However after 2 months the pieces that close to cover the lens became detached and would not always reveal the lens...which of course means no pictures.
We sent the camera back since it was still under warranty, only to find out that the warranty did not cover that part of the camera. Now I may have kids, but I keep my camera out of reach. Frustrated by the fact that it would cost as much to fix it as it would to buy a new camera, we went ahead and ordered the same camera again. It had good ratings, and we figured that the lens issue was a fluke, and after all we w ... ere happy with the actual pictures.
I got the new camera today, and the microphone does not work. Already scheduled to return it. Fool me once... I guess I had this coming. Now I'm back in search of a good, affordable digital camera. I'm beginning to believe this does not exist. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Point and Shoot
Got my Canon to give me a smaller camera to carry in my pocket while duck hunting. Good, handy size, with excellent pics. Just point and shoot. Even did a video while Goose hunting in Maryland. Got good vid without having a big bulky camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Nice Body Color; Easy To Use; Small / Compact
Cons: None
Bought this for our 12 year old daughter. Love that it[...]has its own rechargeable battery and she, of course, loves the color.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: This is a great little camera with easy to use point and shoot features. Can customoze your picture taking very easily. Light weight and handy to keep in purse.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: This camera weighs next to nothing and takes fabulous photos. Its easy to use. Even I was able to load up jpegs onto my computer and email them with ease. Its simple, yet taken off AUTO setting, this Canon can do a whole lot more for more serious photographers.It even shoots a movie or self portraits. I highly recommend this Canon. Its a winner and moron proof.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Easy to use and takes good pictures.
Item.Review:
Pros: Ease of use and size.
Cons: Lots of options to choose from... can be confusing.
I'm very happy with this camera, so far. I've used it over the holidays and on vacaton. It's best to take a moment to think before you click....you need to focus the picture well and set the frame. Really easy to use and fits well in my pocket or purse.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: size, easy to use, long rechargeable battery life
Cons: viewing screen grainey
I love the size of the camera. The viewing screen is extremely grainey but the picture doesn't come out grainey. Some of the pictures are blurred but that could just be the user who is in error.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD; Good Image Quality; Small / Compact; Good in Low Light
I'm a big fan of Canon cameras. Owned a older one for years. This one has great picture quality, and great lighting in low light. Still learning how to use all the features.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small / Compact; Nice Body Color
Cons: Poor Image Quality; Shows an Error
The camera wasn't working properly when I received it. It showed constantly an Error message. Very blurry pictures. I had to return it and I am afraid to purchase the same one.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: Bought this for my wife who normally uses my SLR backup - Canon 40D. She wanted something small enough to carry around in her purse for snapshot type of pictures. It is taking her a it of time to get used to not looking through a viewfinder, but other than that she is pleased. I was worried about noise levels with all those pixels being squeezed into a samll point and shoot sensor but the initial photos look great. It certainly is compact and simple to use. Wold prefer a viewfinder but they are hard to find in these little cameras.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Awesome Camera; LIGHT COMPACT; GREAT PICS; Cool color
Cons: Don't know any
So far, I really like it. It's small & compact enought to carry anywhere. It takes great pics & has cool features.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I bought this camera as a Xmas present for my girlfriend whose old camera took really awful pictures. This tiny camera delivers pictures with great colors, it's easy to use, and has a stylish design. In addition, at this price is was a total bargain.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great for quick startup time and amazing pictures
Item.Review:
Pros: Photo quality, fast start up, and battery life.
Cons: Nothing
This camera is the best point and shoot camera I have ever used for several reasons. Number one, it feels and looks great. It starts up and is able to snap a picture within seconds which is great for action shots one when your trying to catch a moving target. The battery life is great, lasts several days with moderate use and 2 days with heavy use. The pictures taken are great as well. Many people comment on my pictures expecting a larger and more expensive camera to have taken them. The cannon name is also a plus! I would recommend this produce to anyone who is looking for a great price for a great product .

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Good Image Quality; Easy To Use; Fast/accurate auto-focus; Small / Compact
I have a Canon DSLR that I love. However, it is bulky to carry around for everyday photo opportunities. I purchased the Canon PS 1300 for the Canon name/reputation and its size. The camera seems so small compared to the DSLR. It will take some getting used to, but I have been very happy with the images captured thus far.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: great camera, nice quality and easy to use
Item.Review:
Pros: everything
Cons: nothing
love this camera. its small but powerful. takes excellent pictures in macro and many different features to it. great battery life and nice compact charger. great for a beginner or someone who would just like a nice small digital camera to take around instead of a digital SLR.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Buy the Sony Cyber-shot DSC W330 instead!
Item.Review:
Pros: Good picture quality, easy to use
Cons: Squeaky winding noise when it not doing anything
First off, after having this camera for ONE DAY, it made a "squeaky-winding" noise. Even when it was making videos. I know that making videos is not the purpose of this camera, but it should not be doing that. Then, I went back to the store to exchange for the same one and the guy there said that another one was doing it, so I just exchanged it for the Sony Cyber-shot DSC W330. Which is a much better camera. I was specifically looking for a camera with auto-focus and I didn't realize that the Canon one didn't have it when I purchased it. So I am much happier that I got the Sony camera. ...but, the pictures turned out pretty good.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: Got this camera as a gift for my mother. She needed something reliable and simple to use yet. A professional photographer myself, I knew Canon would be a quality product. It did not disappoint. My mom loves it, the compact feel and quality photos and video. The rechargeable battery and image stabilizer were what hooked me.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Picture quality and size of camera.
Cons: No instuction booklet w/ the camera
For the money, this camera is awesome! The picture quality is great and it has many features. My only complaint about it is that it does not come w/ an instructions booklet. You have to go online and download it if you want it. With so many features, you have to have the instructions to figure out how to maximize the camera's functions.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: It's a really handy camera to have on me at all times. I usually shoot with a Canon DSLR. This gives me a lot of the functions I find on my D40 but in a point and shoot. I'm pretty happy with it. My last canon point and shoot lasted me 8 years. When you think about it, the cost over 8 years is pretty nominal.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small / Compact; Good Image Quality; Easy To Use; Good in Low Light; Nice Body Color
I have the Canon SD1200 IS and like it a lot. A friend liked it a lot and asked me for one. Since it has been replaced by the Canon SD1300 IS picked it out for her.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I've been using every type of camera out there in the world, and this one is great for the price. It's lightweight, small, and has a nice range of features for a point and shoot. I haven't been able to use it a ton, but so far it has been great! ...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I actually researched this camera for a friend. I saw the photos it took, and bought one for myself. The camera is small, lightweight, and takes very good shots. In my opinion, one of the best P and S out there. As with all P and S, a bit of flash lag, but not much. Good color balance, anti-shake and zoom. Sturdy little thing, and fits in a pocket.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Perfect Camera For Point And Shoot
Item.Review:
Pros: Great Zoom; Good in Low Light; Nice Body Color; Good Image Stabilization
Perfect camera for point and shoot without complicating the settings. Very compact and easy to handle.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Great Zoom; Good Image Stabilization; Good in Low Light; Nice Body Color
Cons: Zoom lever
Nice camera for the price. Zoom lever is alittle difficut to use being on top with the picture shot button. Takes some getting use to.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Ease of use and it's features.
Cons: PC software. Some won't load. We use file manager to download pictures.
This camera makes good pictures easy. If you want a compact camera that takes very clear pictures automatically, then I'd suggest looking at this one. Even the macro setting is automatic. Some of the software wouldn't load after trying several times, but to be honest, we didn't need it anyway. The computer's file manager will get you access to the camera's memory and any image editor will work then. We were going to buy a Sony rated at 14 megapixels, but after comparing it with this one, we chose the Canon.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small size
Cons: nothing so far
If you are looking for a small camera that takes good pictures this should be a good fit. I had a Canon camera before this that used AA batteries and it was very bulky compared to this camera. You can easily take this one with you in your pocket. It shoots faster than my previous camera too. It's not an SLR camera but meets my needs for most situations.
I used the fireworks mode over the fourth and it worked pretty well. I also use the kids & pets shooting mode with continuous shooting and it is fast enough for me especially when there us a lot of light. The quality of pictures is good too.
Over all I would recommend this camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Great Zoom; Good in Low Light; Nice Body Color; Short Lag Time; Good Image Stabilization
This product is great, I love it! It takes great pictures! I got everything in the deal[...] I LOVE THIS CAMERA!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Great Zoom; Short Lag Time; Nice Body Color; Good Image Stabilization; Good in Low Light
this is a great camera and I would recommend it to anyone. It is easy to us and sharp looking.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review: I would recommend this camera. It's compact size is PERFECT. It fits inside a little clutch or your back pocket. I got the chocolate color and absolutely love it. The quality of pictures is excellent, and response time is fairly fast. I am getting some blurred pictures but it's probably because I haven't played with the settings enough yet. I would highly recommend! ...

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Can't go wrong with the SD1300 IS
Item.Review: The best part about the Canon SD1300 is that it works right out of the box. Great crisp photos. Everything is intuitive and you can give it to your grandmother or an experienced photographer and get great pictures. If you want to utilize the more advanced features, like forced flash, it's a simple setting. A very minor nit: I wish they would put the battery alignment arrow on the camera body, not just the charger. Although you can't put the battery in backward, it would make it easier to align. Enjoy this great camera!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.ReviewTitle: Excellent Camera for Personal, Amateur Photography
Item.Review:
Pros: Easy-to-use, Quick snap-time
Cons: Wouldn't recommend for photography enthusiasts
I bought this camera to take pictures and videos on vacations. It has served this purpose perfectly. I like that quick response time from the time you press the snapshot button to the time the picture is actually taken. Pictures are clear and there are plenty of options to customize your shots. I would definitely recommend this camera to someone who needs an everyday-use digital camera.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Takes great pictures, battery life is awesome
This is the best camera I have ever owned. After going through 3 nikon's I decided to try another brand of camera. I played around with this one in the store and fell in love with it. I got it home and took a ton of pictures and they all turned out great because of the auto focus. I haven't charged the battery in 3 days and it's still fully charged and I use the camera a lot. It's easy to use and I would definitely tell anyone to buy it.

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
Item.Review:
Pros: Small slim size, lightweight, silver color, nice shape, good looking, excellent battery recharger without cord
Cons: Nice if it were easier to use and less expensive
This is a great little camera! I love the small size. It is light and can easliy fit into a handbag or pocket. I was delighted to see how thin and small it was and that the camera was not heavy to carry around. The silver color is nice. A friend recommended this camera to me. Photos are clear and good. I would recommend it to others. There are so many digital cameras and choices out there it can be confusing, but thankfully a close friend identified this camera as an excellent one. It is well worth the money to buy this excellent camera!

Item.Item: Canon PowerShot ELPH SD1300 12.1 MP Digital Camera (Silver)
